{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3180122,"name":"John","username":"JaBong","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/439d5e/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-04-03T21:58:43.895Z","cooked":"

We’re using some rev six-pin joiner boards to make some longer sensor cable to run from NEOs to the Spark Maxs.

We’ve been having some trouble at our last few competitions with the boards not holding the cable, so they get disconnected and disable the NEOs.

We don’t want to use tape for risk of damaging the fragile sensor cables, so our solution has been to use hot glue and a heat gun to repair/disconnect.

Is there a better way to hold the boards together?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-04-03T21:59:12.244Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":32,"reads":184,"readers_count":183,"score":216.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":432879,"topic_slug":"how-to-secure-six-pin-joiner-boards","display_username":"John","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.revrobotics.com/rev-11-1277/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"JST PH 6-pin Joiner Board - 4 Pack - REV Robotics","clicks":46}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57132,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"(electronics)"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-secure-six-pin-joiner-boards/432879/1","custom_user_title":"(electronics)","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3180135,"name":"Brett B Bonner","username":"bbonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bbonner/{size}/155176_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-03T22:25:38.457Z","cooked":"
JaBong:

Is there a better way to hold the boards together?

Best practice is whenever possible to locate your SparkMAX near enough to the motor to not require extending the encoder cable. Extending power and CAN is much easier to do reliably. But if you can’t do that…

Hot glue is an option to stop the connectors from loosening. If you need a heat gun to take it apart you’re probably overdoing it, though; a little blob or two should be enough, and if you’re tugging it hard enough to dislodge that you need to fix that problem; these boards shouldn’t have any tension on them. (Making the connectors not pull out under tension with large amounts of glue just means you’re going to break a wire instead of popping the connector out.)

Obviously with an extended encoder cable you’re extending your 3 motor power wires too, and they are significantly stronger. So you might be able to ziptie the encoder wires on either side of the joiner board to the power wires for strain relief so they, and not the encoder wires, absorb a (small) pulling force. Be careful not to make the zipties so tight that they themselves damage the encoder wires, though!

We wrap a thin zip tie through the conductors (carefully!) and retain using that.

We used electrical tape but also heat shrink would work well too.

If the connectors on the ends of the cables are coming out of the Joiner Board, there is tension in the cables. Attaching the connectors to the Joiner Board with anything just means that a different thing will fail. In this case, it is most likely the thin wires in the cables that will fail.

All wires should be tied down so that they are never under any tension. There should be slack where they connect to a board or other connector. Check to see if any tension appears when the associated mechanisms move (do this by hand). Also check if there is flex in your chassis or the electrical panels that can apply tension to the cables.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-04-04T05:06:03.461Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":78,"readers_count":77,"score":20.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":432879,"topic_slug":"how-to-secure-six-pin-joiner-boards","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-secure-six-pin-joiner-boards/432879/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3180422,"name":"Abi","username":"thesteminist","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thesteminist/{size}/179827_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-04T10:31:51.999Z","cooked":"

We have a 70 inch data cable that we have running to a motor on the end effector that’s mounted on the end of a telescoping arm. Being real with you… We soldered it. And we’ve had no issues. If you have someone who has enough patience and skill to separate the six wires, solder them together, and heat shrink each strand so they don’t touch, you could eliminate the need for a joiner board altogether so long as you don’t mind re-soldering if you have to replace the motor.
